## □□□□□□□□□□□□ □□ □□□ □□□□□□□□□□ □□□□□

□□□□□□□□□□□ □□□□□ □□ □□ □□ □□□□ □□□□□□□ □□□□□ □□□ □□□□□□□□□□□□ □□ □□□□□□□.

Without coordinates, we could say something like, "We get $\maroonD{B'}$ by translating $\blueD{B}$ down and to the right."

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/4cefbcb284fe4e9faa7bb67dc1c55f22534097f9)

But that's not very precise. If we use a coordinate grid, we can say something more exact: "We get $\maroonD{B'}$ by translating $\blueD{B}$ by 5 units to the right and 4 units down."

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/78f0c6ffa4f435bb27d80c75adbee450ed6d7a71)

More compactly, we can describe this as **a translation by $\langle 5,-4 \rangle$.**

□□□ □□□□□□□□ □□□□ □□ □□□□□ □□ □□□ □ □□□□□ □□ □□□ □□□□□□□□ □□□□□ □□ □□□□□□□□□ □□□□□□□ □□ □□□□□□□. □□□□□□□□□, □ □□□□□□□□□□□ □□ □□□ □□□□ □□ □□□□□□□□□ □□ □□□ □□□□□ □□□□□ □□□□□ □□□□□□□□.

###□□□-□□□□□□ □□□ □□□□□□

For any transformation, we have the **pre-image** figure, which is the figure we are performing the transformation upon, and the **image** figure, which is the result of the transformation. For example, in our translation, the pre-image point was $\blueD{B}$ and the image point was $\maroonD{B'}$.

Note that we indicated the image by $\maroonD{B'}$, pronounced B prime. It is common, when working with transformations, to use the same letter for the image and the pre-image, simply adding the "prime" suffix to the image.
